children: The physical finding demonstrated in the image is Pemberton sign, which consists of congestion and erythema of the face and eventual cyanosis and distress associated with raising the arms above the head (

). This sign is associated with substernal or retroclavicular goiters, mediastinal masses, and superior vena cava syndrome and is caused by compression of the trachea, esophagus, or neck veins when patients flex or elevate their arms.
